<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 277, 232, 294]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[836, 278, 907, 294]]<|/det|>
9709/31  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 303, 312, 319]]<|/det|>
Paper 3 Pure Mathematics 3  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 303, 908, 320]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 329, 908, 345]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 357, 395, 373]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 384, 390, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 418, 225, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 435, 875, 632]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 664, 216, 679]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 680, 732, 712]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 75.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
On a sketch of an Argand diagram, shade the region whose points represent complex numbers \(z\) satisfying the inequalities \(|z| \geqslant 2\) and \(|z - 1 + \mathrm{i}| \leqslant 1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 437, 92]]<|/det|>
The parametric equations of a curve are

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[364, 100, 631, 119]]<|/det|>
\[x = 3 - \cos 2\theta ,\quad y = 2\theta +\sin 2\theta ,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 127, 240, 145]]<|/det|>
for \(0 < \theta < \frac{1}{2}\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 161, 298, 190]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}} = \cot \theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 168, 920, 186]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 74, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 270, 92]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[361, 94, 636, 114]]<|/det|>
\[\log_{10}(2x + 1) = 2\log_{10}(x + 1) - 1.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 116, 492, 135]]<|/det|>
Give your answers correct to 3 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 116, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 77, 97, 96]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 77, 146, 96]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 75, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
By sketching a suitable pair of graphs, show that the equation \(\cos \mathrm{e}x = 1 + \mathrm{e}^{-\frac{1}{2}x}\) has exactly two roots in the interval \(0< x< \pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 92, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 460, 186, 477]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 457, 586, 477]]<|/det|>
The sequence of values given by the iterative formula

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[379, 484, 616, 523]]<|/det|>
\[x_{n + 1} = \pi -\sin^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{\mathrm{e}^{-\frac{1}{2}x_n} + 1}\right),\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 527, 608, 547]]<|/det|>
with initial value \(x_{1} = 2\), converges to one of these roots.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 558, 920, 593]]<|/det|>
Use the formula to determine this root correct to 2 decimal places. Give the result of each iteration to 4 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 574, 920, 593]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
Express \(\sqrt{6} \cos \theta + 3 \sin \theta\) in the form \(R \cos (\theta - \alpha)\), where \(R > 0\) and \(0^\circ < \alpha < 90^\circ\). State the exact value of \(R\) and give \(\alpha\) correct to 2 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[885, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 715, 92]]<|/det|>
Hence solve the equation \(\sqrt{6} \cos \frac{1}{3} x + 3 \sin \frac{1}{3} x = 2.5\), for \(0^\circ < x < 360^\circ\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 72, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 99, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 73, 698, 92]]<|/det|>
Verify that \(-1 + \sqrt{5}\mathrm{i}\) is a root of the equation \(2x^{3} + x^{2} + 6x - 18 = 0.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 450, 91]]<|/det|>
Find the other roots of this equation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 74, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 777, 92]]<|/det|>
The coordinates \((x, y)\) of a general point of a curve satisfy the differential equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[423, 100, 571, 129]]<|/det|>
\[x\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x} = (1 - 2x^2)y,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 136, 462, 155]]<|/det|>
for \(x > 0\). It is given that \(y = 1\) when \(x = 1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 168, 710, 186]]<|/det|>
Solve the differential equation, obtaining an expression for \(y\) in terms of \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 168, 920, 186]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
Hence obtain the expansion of \(\mathrm{f}(x)\) in ascending powers of \(x\), up to and including the term in \(x^{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 88, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 106, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[292, 83, 740, 234]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 252, 695, 272]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curve \(y = (2 - x)\mathrm{e}^{-\frac{1}{2}x}\), and its minimum point \(M\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 284, 148, 303]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 284, 420, 303]]<|/det|>
Find the exact coordinates of \(M\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 285, 920, 303]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 74, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the shaded region bounded by the curve and the axes. Give your answer in terms of e.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
Given instead that the acute angle between the directions of the two lines is \(\cos^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{6}\right)\), find the two possible values of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]
